properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected beginning Sunday night. Total snowfall: 10 cm or more. Locations: Northwestern New Brunswick. Time span: Sunday night through Monday morning. Remarks: A low pressure system will approach from the west on Sunday. Snow will develop ahead of the low Sunday night and persist into Monday morning. The snow will be wet and mixed at times with rain or freezing rain. Current indications suggest that total snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-14T13:26:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-13T21:27:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1580033109.2020
Area: Edmundston and Madawaska County, western half of Restigouche County, Campbellton and eastern half of Restigouche County, Grand Falls and Victoria County, Mount Carleton - Renous Highway
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A Colorado low will intensify over New England and affect Eastern Quebec Sunday and Monday. This storm will bring snow at times heavy, strong to high winds and even rain. Snowfall amounts could exceed 15 centimetres over several areas. Over the tip of the Gaspé Peninsula and Anticosti Island, precipitation will mainly fall as rain. Rainfall amounts between 20 and 30 millimetres are expected there. Southeasterly winds could gust from 70 to 90 kilometres per hour over the tip of the Gaspé Peninsula and the Lower North Shore on Monday. The combination of these winds and the fact that we are currently in a period of high tidal ranges may produce breaking sea conditions at Gaspé-Percé, on Anticosti Island and on the Lower North Shore Monday afternoon. Due to this system's complexity, it is still too early to predict with certainty the precipitation amounts and those regions most affected. More information on this system's development will be provided as it becomes available. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-14T12:26:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-13T20:27:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3940487498.2020
Area: Manic-5 area, Manic-3 area, Chutes-des-Passes - Pipmuacan Reservoir area, Labrieville area, Forestville area, Les Escoumins area, La Malbaie area, Baie-Saint-Paul area, Apica Mountain area, Grands-Jardins Park area, l'Étape area, Rimouski Wildlife Reserve area, Amqui area, Matapédia area, Murdochville area, Mont-Albert area, Grande-Rivière - Cascapédia area, New-Richmond - Bonaventure area, Restigouche - Carleton area, Chandler area, New Carlisle - Port-Daniel area, Forillon National Park - Gaspé area, Percé area, Baie-Comeau, Baie-Trinité area, Sept-Îles - Port-Cartier area, Minganie, Anticosti, Témiscouata

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions are expected on Saturday. Snow combined with gusts reaching to 70 km/h will reduce visibilities to near zero. ### Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-14T14:31:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-13T22:32:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3140614569.2020
Area: Ivujivik
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected over some areas. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Locations: mainly inland sections of eastern Newfoundland. Time span: Saturday afternoon until Sunday morning. Remarks: The highest snowfall amounts can be expected inland and over higher terrain. Most coastal areas should see much lower snowfall amounts as the snow occasionally mixes with or changes to rain. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-14T11:07:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-13T19:08:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2996609228.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, St. John's and vicinity, Burin Peninsula, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Terra Nova

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 10 cm is expected. A Pacific storm will continue tracking across the B.C. interior tonight, Approximately 10 cm of snow has already today, with a further 5 cm expected this evening before the snow eases. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A low pressure centre over the South Coast this morning will move into the southern BC interior in the afternoon. In the wake of the low, westerly winds of 70 km/h gusting to 90 will develop in Greater Victoria near Juan de Fuca Strait this afternoon. The winds will ease this evening. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-14T04:26:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-13T12:27:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0441984470.2020
Area: Greater Victoria
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A Pacific storm will continue moving across the BC interior today. Heavy snow will persist over the Coquihalla Highway from Hope to Merritt with the heaviest accumulations expected this afternoon. Approximately 20 cm of snow has fallen since last night. Additional snowfall amounts of 25 to 35 cm can be expected by Saturday morning, before the snow tapers to flurries early Saturday afternoon. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-14T10:05:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-13T18:06:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0740210758.2020
Area: Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 15 cm is expected. A Pacific storm moving across the BC interior will continue to bring snow to the Boundary region this morning. Temperatures will rise above freezing later today allowing the snow to become mixed with rain. Additional snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm can be expected this morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions have developed in Sachs Harbour this afternoon. With another 4 to 8 cm of falling snow and winds strenthening with gusts up to 70 km/h, blizzard conditions will continue through tonight and Saturday. Blizzard conditions are expected to end by Sunday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-14T13:30:48-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Heavy snow has developed over Whistler and the Sea to Sky Highway north of Squamish overnight. Snow at times heavy is expected to continue this morning. Additional snowfall amounts of 5 cm are expected. Snow will ease to a few flurries late this morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow.
